item.title: Joe Biden downplays chances of UK-US trade deal
item.description: The US president's comments come as he met Boris Johnson for talks in the White House.

item.title: CF Industries: Government to meet CO2 firm's costs to start plant
item.description: It comes after one industry group warned shoppers could start noticing gaps on shelves within days.

item.title: Melbourne earthquake: Tremor rattles southeast Australia
item.description: A 5.8 magnitude earthquake rattles Australia's second largest city, causing damage to buildings.

item.title: Pen Farthing: Charity Commission scrutinises Afghan animal rescue
item.description: Around 150 animals were evacuated to the UK, along with Paul "Pen" Farthing and animal shelter staff.

item.title: Catalogue of errors led to Â£1bn of state pension underpayments
item.description: The National Audit Office says 134,000 pensioners, mostly women, were affected by a preventable scandal.

item.title: Overprescribing of medicines must stop, says government
item.description: Some prescribed treatments are unnecessary and even harmful, says government-commissioned report.

item.title: Gabby Petito: Body found in Wyoming is missing 'van life' blogger
item.description: A coroner says the 22-year-old's death was a homicide but gives no details as to how she died.

item.title: Sharon Graham: Unite leader to skip Labour conference
item.description: Sharon Graham insists she is not snubbing party leader Keir Starmer but it's a matter of priorities.

item.title: 'No clear end to HS2 cost and delays' say MPs
item.description: The Public Accounts Committee is "increasingly alarmed" about key parts of the rail project.

item.title: Surrogacy on the rise in England and Wales
item.description: The number of parents having a baby this way has nearly quadrupled in the last decade, figures show.

item.title: President Biden urges unity in first UN speech amid tensions with allies
item.description: Joe Biden called for cooperation in his first speech as US president to the UN General Assembly.

item.title: Taliban ask to speak at UN General Assembly in New York
item.description: The group wants to address world leaders, weeks after ousting Afghanistan's former government.

item.title: GCSE media studies to cover Rashford's food campaign
item.description: Pupils will learn how social media can make an impact, by studying the player's campaign work.

item.title: The Papers: UK-US trade deal speculation and energy bill fears
item.description: The focus is on the future of UK-US trade after the Washington DC meeting between Boris Johnson and Joe Biden.

item.title: Life at 50C: Heat hitting home in Australia
item.description: Cities like Sydney are already experiencing extremely hot days because of climate change.

item.title: Old PPE masks find new life fighting plastic waste
item.description: All schools and colleges in Cornwall will be given litter pickers made from old hospital masks.

item.title: Seaside suburb inspires worldwide photo collaboration
item.description: Photographers around the world worked together on a seafront exhibition in Portobello, Edinburgh.

item.title: Museum of the Year: Colchester gallery Firstsite wins Â£100,000 prize
item.description: Alongside top exhibitions, its cafÃ© became a canteen offering free school meals during the pandemic.

item.title: Harry Styles haunts Noel Gallagher with win at Ivor Novello Awards
item.description: It's eight years after Noel Gallagher praised the event because "clowns like One Direction" don't win.

item.title: The night my baby died as I gave birth in prison
item.description: Louise Powell says her baby died "due to errors" made after she went into labour in prison.

item.title: Covid vaccine stockpiles: Are 241m doses at risk of going to waste?
item.description: Joe Biden wants more global vaccine equality but the US and other nations have not backed promises with action.

item.title: Afghanistan: 'I feel betrayed. We feel left behind'
item.description: An Afghan interpreter affected by an email data breach at the MoD says he feels betrayed by the UK.

item.title: World War Two: The brothers who fled Nazi occupation by kayak
item.description: The "Engelandvaarders" who paddled from the Netherlands to England 80 years ago.

item.title: COP 26: How much is the developing world getting to fight climate change?
item.description: Are rich countries living up to their climate promises to the developing world?

item.title: German elections: Businesses face future without Merkel
item.description: Many companies in Germany are focused on short-term survival in the hope of medium-term revival.

item.title: Fifa 22 soundtrack: Why getting on it is a 'bucket list' moment
item.description: This is what it means to young artists to be featured on the playlist for the latest Fifa game.

item.title: CEO Secrets: 'In my business, you eat what you kill'
item.description: Music executive Riki Bleau shares his business advice for our CEO Secrets series.

item.title: Abba's Bjorn Ulvaeus launches campaign to fix Â£500m music royalty problem
item.description: Bjorn Ulvaeus launches a campaign to ensure musicians don't miss out on unpaid royalties.

item.title: England hit 10 past Luxembourg to extend free-scoring start under Wiegman
item.description: Ellen White, Alex Greenwood and Millie Bright each score twice as England thump Luxembourg in their one-sided Women's World Cup qualifier.

item.title: Tahuhu inspires New Zealand to victory over England
item.description: Lea Tahuhu stars with the ball for New Zealand as England slip to a three-wicket defeat in the third game of the five-match one-day international series.

item.title: Championship Stoke knock out wasteful Watford in EFL Cup
item.description: Two late goals give Championship side Stoke City a surprise win over a wasteful Watford in the Carabao Cup third round.

item.title: Scotland score seven to beat Faroe Islands
item.description: Scotland cruise to victory against the Faroe Islands in their first ever qualifier at Hampden Park to maintain a perfect start to their World Cup bid.

item.title: 'You have more chance of climbing Everest than playing in Ryder Cup' - Harrington's message to players
item.description: Europe captain Padraig Harrington delivers 'powerful' opening message to his players at the start of Ryder Cup week in Whistling Straits.

item.title: Moselle Open: Andy Murray beats Ugo Humbert to reach second round
item.description: Andy Murray fights back from a set down to defeat world number 26 Ugo Humbert in the first round of the Moselle Open.

item.title: Austin impresses as QPR upset Everton on penalties
item.description: Championship side QPR upset Everton on penalties, after 2-2 draw, to reach the last 16 of the Carabao Cup.

item.title: Back to school: How are pupils being kept Covid-safe?
item.description: Most 12 to 15-year-olds will be vaccinated at school, to help limit disruption to their education.

item.title: Is it safe to vaccinate our child? And other questions
item.description: We answer some of your questions about vaccinating 12-15 year-olds, the booster vaccine and other topics.

item.title: Travel update: What are the new rules for holidays in Europe and the US?
item.description: The rules on foreign travel to and from England are being simplified.

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in my area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: Covid passports: How do I get one and when will I need it?
item.description: People in Scotland will need to be fully vaccinated to go to clubs, sporting events and concerts.

item.title: Covid rules: What's in England's 'Winter Plan'?
item.description: Lockdown rules have changed across the UK, but some restrictions remain in place.

item.title: Coronavirus: Where does the government borrow billions from?
item.description: How does it work when a government wants to borrow money, and when does it have to pay it back?

item.title: Universal credit: When will the Â£20 increase stop?
item.description: The government has confirmed the Â£20 boost will end in the autumn.

item.title: What are the travel rules for Spain, Portugal, Malta and other holiday hotspots?
item.description: What you need to know about going to Portugal, Spain, Greece, France, Malta, Italy and Turkey.

item.title: Covid: People are vaccinated - so why are there so many cases?
item.description: More than four out of five UK adults are now fully vaccinated, but daily case rates remain high.

item.title: Long Covid: What is it and what are the symptoms?
item.description: Significant numbers have had long-term problems after recovering from the original infection.

item.title: Paul Rusesabagina: From Hotel Rwanda hero to convicted terrorist
item.description: Paul Rusesabagina, who was portrayed in Hotel Rwanda, has gone from national hero to enemy of the state.

item.title: Fake Paralympians boss: 'I didn't know about cheating'
item.description: The man fined for sending non-disabled athletes to the Sydney Paralympics breaks his silence.

item.title: Muriel Gardiner: The heiress who saved countless lives
item.description: Muriel Gardiner's courage fighting fascism in Austria inspired an Oscar-winning film. Who was she?

item.title: Hushpuppi - the Instagram influencer and international fraudster
item.description: How Nigerian Ramon Abbas went from a romance scammer to a so-called "Billionaire Gucci Master".

item.title: âHavana syndromeâ¯â and the mystery of the microwaves
item.description: The BBC investigates a mystery illness dubbed "Havana syndrome" that has affected American diplomats and spies.
